messages.content: afaik this.network.timestamp is UInt64 already, you need to get it first
Do you thing it's save? can a node change the timestamp?

i'd guess the person producing a block decides the timestamp, and its up to the protocol to verify the timestamp is in a certain range for the block to be accepted, this is how its usually done in my experience
i dont know how exactly mina does it, i'm sure @garethtdavies know how a timestamp is determined when a block is produced
it really depends on what your goal is, the block number should be ‘precise’ while the timestamp probably isnt and can vary within a limit
I think it’s just the start time of the slot. I’ll have to double check that.
Nice, I didn't know the genesis timestamp was already exposed by the daemon in a grapgql query! I should use that
Thanks, I will try to use that
